pros:
-HR Department is responsive and helpful
-Salaries are competitive and Wayne is low cost of living
-Benefits are very good
cons:
-Work-life balance
-Expectation to live in small community
-Supervisor expectations don't match the investment in resources and support

pros: Public four-year college that is growing.
cons: The college is growing because it is open enrollment.

pros:
Small, so you really get to know your students. 
The students for the most part are really nice to work with. They are the best thing about Wayne State College.
cons:
The President's nickname is "Little Hitler." That says it all.
Top down leadership. Doesn't like nor listens to faculty.
Favoritism, nepotism, and sexism is standard within the culture.
Policies are ignored, for instance, a report of discrimination was completely ignored by leadership.
Profit-driven mentality. The current leadership from the dean's level on up is just interested in bottom line. They want more students (more revenue) and higher retention, but do not want to pay for more faculty. A 'Walmart" mentality. Current faculty are stretched to their limit, and completely over-worked in trying to serve the student needs.

pros: If you need a job for the summer it definitely works
cons: It’s alright there but need more staff members

pros: Benefits are better than average. The pay is below average and is terrible for staff positions. It can be a nice small town to raise your family. The students range from inspired to clueless. Your colleagues will depend on the department and school. Beautiful campus. You will need to create and pay for your own professional development opportunities. You might get reimbursed for travel or supplies if you have a good relationship with your department head or dean. There is a great deal of service work and advising that is required. If you enjoy teaching and working with students this could be a great place to start your career.
cons:
The college has had issues keeping faculty and staff. The administration doesn't seem to communicate with all faculty or staff on a regular basis. There is a palatable town gown divide that can be felt at certain businesses and with landlords. 
Work life balance is mentioned as a concept but doesn't seem to be supported by college policies. Many of my colleagues have too many students or advisees. Student services seems understaffed but this could be due to the pandemic.
Some staff members are treated badly by their supervisors. The leader of one of the areas says terrible things about their employees to other staff. It doesn't seem legal. It is disconcerting. The college is always searching for more workers in this area. There seems to be rancor in some areas of the college about past deeds of the administration. It's a theme across campus and brings down morale. 
Budgets for departments are low across the aboard and everything is on a 2 year budget plan? It makes it difficult to plan for replacement equipment or purchases. I've seen colleagues struggle to get basics to run their programs.
Some professors, staff and students are conservative. If you are liberal, you may need to re-calibrate your language to be successful with students. The area is rural and remote. Be prepared to drive two hours for more varied foodstuffs. If you are single, this might not be the place for you unless you enjoy long distance relationships.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Wayne, NE
pros:
Supportive Faculty and Admins
Plenty of dedicated students
cons: Middle of nowhere... must like small town life to be happy there. Lacking in diversity, but not too much the university can do considering the demographics of the area

review_title: Great program, decent pay, rough winters
pros: Friendly faculty, great community, and professional development opportunities
cons: Winters were brutal and not much to do in the town. I would live in Sioux City if you plan to work there, but that’s a 2 hour commute everyday. Students even complain about the location.

pros: Good class load, opportunities for overloads
cons: Administrators are small minded and punitive

pros: High pay and wonderful benefits. Wonderful colleagues too!
cons: Rural location and long winters

pros: nice community, great coworkers, good compensation
cons: Time consuming, less privacy, unwanted meetings

pros: 5 hours per week office hours
cons: Lack of experience in dept

review_title: a very steady part-time job for a college student, great fit for a full time student looking for some extra money.
job_title: Network and Technology Services Technician in Wayne, NE
pros: Flexible schedules, consistent hours, supervisors are really understanding, and playful work environment.
cons: If campus does not close you still have to work regardless if you have classes or not and pay is only $9.50 goes up my .50 a year.

pros: You get your own room. It looks good on a resume. Paid of full  room and can be a great deal financially.
cons: It's a major time commitment. You don't have much privacy. You are held to higher standards.You have to return to campus early.

pros: Great team of people, most try hard
cons: Rules and management policies are antiquted, VERY antiquated

job_title: Maintenance Repair Worker III in Wayne, NE
pros: Good benefits, it's an opportunity to learn a lot
cons: Bad pay, my paycheck only pays for the roof over my head and my children's daycare and my position is one of the higher pay grades.

cons: Depending on program there is better higher level education offered elsewhere, parking
